lines.text: I don't want to go to Brooklyn. You can't make me. I don't *want* to go to Brooklyn.
None of us want to, bud, but we all gotta go sooner or later.
He's talking to a salami. He thinks it's a fan dancer.
[last lines]
In fact, I don't think I'm ever going to see Buster again.
[Edwin hears the spooky Buster music and gasps]

[angrily]
Buster!

[popping out of a box]
I'm a little devil, ain't I?
Do you think you'll be coming back tomorrow?
Oh, by all means. I enjoy it here very much, uh, I love the smell of leather bindings.
Did you say you sing and dance in a night club?
No, I work in a bakery. But, a lot of people take me for Lana Turner.

[Talking on the phone]
But, I just have to talk to the District Attorney about a young man he arrested. He's not really out of his mind. I upset him because he's not used to girls.
[repeated line]
Potato salad!
Do you remember you once told me you wouldn't be found dead in Brooklyn?
Yeah, I remember. That was the only way they could get me here.
I'd like a pint of Prospect Park!
Take it easy, lad. A fellow has to pay his cab fare. What do I owe you, Max?
60 cents, Buzzy.
I'll toss you for it, double or nothing. Give me a coin. Come on, Max. Come on. That a boy. What do you cry?
Tails!
To bad, Max, you lose. Ha-ha-ha!
[Starts to walk away]
Hey Buzzy, my quarter! My quarter!
This guy's money mad. Here you go, Max.
[Buzzy tosses money to Max]

[Surprised]
Five bucks! What a sweetheart.
What a guy!
You know, Mr. Dingle, you have the most extraordinary mind I've ever heard of.
Oh, I wouldn't say that.
You're very modest, aren't you?
Yes, I guess, I am.
That's odd. If I had a mind like yours; in fact, if I had any mind at all; I'd be a brazen hussy! Ha-ha-ha.
Oh! Ha-ha-ha
There! I bet that's the first time you've laughed since you've read Professor Zimmel's inaccuracies of the Phoenician wars. Ha-ha-ha
Ha-ha-ha. Yes, I guess it is, at that. You know, I really enjoy being here.
I'm glad. I like having you.
Edwin, do you always where your hair parted in the middle?
Yes, why?
Why, I never saw anybody look good with their hair that way, except Hedy Lamarr.

[Kicked in the posterior by Edwin Dingle while drinking at a water fountain in Prospect Park]
Why, you!
Good evening.
What do you think you're doing?
Oh, forgive me, it was, it was a scientific experiment.
I'll show you an experiment, Einstein!
Fear is not in the Dingle lexicon, Buster.
Alright, Alright, she's waiting for you. Now, be a good Joe, slip her a kiss and square the beef so she'll know you're on the up and up.
Someday, you won't get away with this, Buzzy. Its a good thing I'm as wacky as you are.
As the little Eskimo girl says, it takes me a little while to get me to warm up.
Mr. Bellew, Can I have your autograph, please, for the guys in my sorority?
Why, certainly, I'm an old Vassar man, myself.
I want to explain about last night.
Well, it better be good. Making me wait hours for potato salad and telephoning me and barking like a dog, meowing like a cat and hooting like an owl.
Ellen.
You've got a nerve, hanging around here. You just got me fired!
I'm sorry, but, I must resort to force.
Oh, now you're a cave man!
Well, the Neanderthal Man had his merits.
You're nutty as a fruit cake!
Calm down, Mr. Bellew. You're as safe as a church.
Your story is satisfactory except for a few minor details.
Well, it was quite dark and I may have slipped up on one or two points.
Yes, in the first place, the tall, thin man with the red beard was a short, fat, fan dancer named Chu-Chu LaVerne!
Holy jumping Republicans, throw this maniac outta here!
